title: What will the 1-month London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) for the U.S. dollar be on May 31, 2017?
preds: Updating for the last day since it doesn't seem like the rate will fall under 1.00
I think the fixing happens in the morning so this one is done unless a less than 1% freak announcement happens in overnight.
Rate keeps creeping higher with only a few more trading days to go. As of yesterday's close 1.0438%, making over 1.0% a near certainty.

Only 8 days (6 trading days) remaining. Down tick in the rate today, so adjusting my forecast accordingly taking into account time errosion and rate change. Assuming 13% volatility for LIBOR, not sure if that is a good assumption or not.

libor is going up secondary to a forecasted FED rate hike in June?  I don't think there will be a rate hike in June. The current $UST2Y is below the Dec 2016 and March 2017 $UST2Y yields when the FED raised.  Of course that could change.
Clean through the 1%-barrier and rising fast. Rising above 1.25% in a few days seems very unlikely

During the last year the 1month LIBOR based on the US dollar has increased twice (between .20% to .25% each time).
The first time was at the time of the US Presidential election.  The second time was just before the debt ceiling deadline.
Unless there is a stock market crash or other large change the rate is unlikely to do more than vacillate.

http://www.global-rates.com/interest-rates/libor/american-dollar/usd-libor-interest-rate-1-month.aspx It's going up from a historic low. Hovering right around 1.00% at the moment. Would like to know what caused the increases on the graph above from the last year (Trump election & Fed rate rises?)

flipping to 70/30 above 1%.  Looks like the trend is up over the last week.  I would have thought political turmoil in the US would leader to a weaker demand for USD and therefore a fall in rates.  Maybe my 1-factor in my head before I head to subway model for work in the morning model is missing some important independent variables.

The last time LIBOR for USD was above 1% was two months ago. It has also been steadily declining since a year ago. At .92778 today and .99411 a month ago, I don't believe it will drop more than .15 in the next 22 days. Source: http://online.wsj.com/mdc/public/page/2_3020-libor.html
The rate has been very stable just under the 1% limit. Let's see if the French elections have an influence.

Clicking on the weekly Libor rate every Friday for the last 4 weeks, gives an estimated 0.84978. The last week libor rate will be higher, but not even close to breaking 1%.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moving_average

The is ''hint" of leveling off is now clear. The rate seems afraid to cross the 1% line. But it is still very close. So let's not overreact and give 40% probability for the [0.75-1[ and 60% probability for the [1-1.25[ interval.

The LIBOR rate has been increasing since the end of 2015 and the reason seems to be changing regulations. This driver is still going on so I think the rate continues to increase but gradually with a small chance for a jump. data:

What will the 1-month London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) for the U.S. dollar be on May 31, 2017?
Forecast: Less than 0.75 = 0%, between 0.75 and 1 % = 0%, between 1 and 1.25% is 75%, between 1.25 and 1.5% =25% and higher than 1.5% =0%.
The 1-month London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor) for the US dollar was 0,98% when this piece was written, according to the Wall Street Journal (www.wsj.com). To examine the history of the Libor for the US dollar, we will look at data from the FRED since January 1986. For the Libor to be between 1% and 1.25% it has to grow at least 2% and less than 27% in about two months.
%∆ Pricet =(〖Price〗_█(t@  )- 〖Price〗_(t-60))/〖Price〗_(t-60)  x 100%. 
There are some gaps in the data and from the last two months we obviously do not know what the growth is 60 days later. Of all the 7575 possible 60-day intervals, 2670, or 35,2%, showed an increase in the Libor of more than 2%. However, if one zooms in to more recent times, this percentage increases to 98.4% (See the upwards sloping line in figure 2). We also have to take into account the possibility of the Libor increasing with more than 27%, since it will end up in the interval from 1.25 to 1.5%. The base rate of such an increase, calculated using the data since 1986, is 4.9%. Yet, similar to the 2% increase, the base rate is 35.7% looking at the data from last year. Therefore, if we take last year’s base rate our default position would be: Probability of Libor in interval 0.75-1% is 1.6%, Probability of Libor in interval 1-1.25% is 62.7% and probability of Libor in interval 1.25-1.5% is 35.7%.
As one compares figure 2 and 3, the resemblance between the two figures is striking. When the banks expect the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) to raise the federal funds rate, as in December last year, the Libor starts increasing before the raise and keeps increasing to about one tenth of a percent point higher than the upper limit of the Federal funds rate. This implies that the Libor mirrors to a large extent the (upper rate of the) federal funds rate. Since the FOMC decided to raise the limit to 1% about one week ago, it is very likely that the Libor will increase to more than 1%. With this information, it is possible to eradicate the 1.6% probability of the Libor not reaching the 1% before the 31st of May. Furthermore, the Libor is also unlikely to reach the 1.25%, since it is rare that the Libor increases to a rate that  is 0.25% higher than the upper limit of the Federal Funds rate. Chances that the FOMC will raise the limit again, in their meeting at the start of May, are slim, since they usually do not raise the rate twice in a row.
A second indicator for a growth in the Libor is the increase in US 10-year Treasury bond yields. Those have been in decline for a long time and finally seem to be on the way back. The growth of the yields can be explained by the economic situation. Employment is rising and unemployment is arguably falling below is natural level and the inflation is also back on track. The increased yields on US bonds cause an increase in the demand for US dollars. This then results in an increase in the Libor for the US dollar. 
In conclusion, the Libor is expected to pass the 1% rate, yet unlikely to pass the 1.25%. Because of the expected growth of the Libor to above the upper limit of the federal funds rate, the chances of the Libor being below 1% are zero. I raise the base rate for the Libor to be between 1 and 1.25% to 75%, since it is unlikely that the Libor will increase to more than 1.25% in comparison to the federal funds rate limit of 1%. The chances of the Libor being between 1.25 and 1.5% will then be 25%, since I deem it very unlikely that the Libor will end higher than 1.5%.
A trade war could create a shock offshore USD funding

Next FOMC meetings are 2/3 May and 13/14 June. Fed futures currently pricing rate increase at 13% in May and 54% in June. 1-month LIBOR currently 0.98%, while 2-month LIBOR at 1.02% and 3-month LIBOR at 1.15% suggest 1-month LIBOR in 1 and 2 months will be higher than current.
<0.75% - seems v unlikely, only if Fed forced to backtrack on current increase
0.75%-1.00% - possible if no increase in May and Fed signals June increase unlikely
1.00%-1.25% - likely range if June increase a possibility still at end May
1.25%-1.50% - only if May increase
>1.50% - only if some form of financial crisis causes spike in inter bank lending
Based upon the jump in 1-Mo. LIBOR from yesterday I am allocating more probability to the 1-1.25 range and less to the .75-1 range.

Interest rate movements are certainly in an uptrend;  I've assigned 0% because I believe a downward move of that magnitude is very, very unlikely (but not truly zero).  The real question is will LIBOR stagnate for the next two months or will it continue on its short-term trend?  I am assigning a greater probability to the status quo.  I am also assigning small probabilities that LIBOR hastens its upward pace and reaches the 1.25% or greater categories.

At this moment the rate is 0.95%. In the last month is rose by 0.17%. So my first guess is 0.95+0.17=1.12%. However, most of the forecasters stay within the [0.75-1[ interval. But the rise seems steady. Because I have no real knowledge on the subject, I give 25% probability for the [0.75-1[ interval and 75% probability for the [1-1.25[ interval.
Not expecting another rate hike. Even if the rates were to rise, the increase wouldn't be reflected by 31 May.

"More importantly, we believe that the Libor-OIS spread (and hence relative Libor rates) will remain cyclically elevated beyond October as banks and investors adjust to a significantly diminished investment base and new rules governing prime funds. " BUT is this a structural change where hedging is removed because rising rates lift all money managers, or is a convenient blindsiding of potential (poststructural?) risks in the offing? Since this article came out, the TED Spread has been going down, but will it also show more volatility in the coming months? What percentage of small banks will survive the Libor tide?
The TED Spread Says That You Shouldn't Be Bullish The Global Economy
http://seekingalpha.com/article/4047538-ted-spread-says-bullish-global-economy

"We show that, in contrast to actual outlays, announcements about future spending robustly lead to a significant and immediate appreciation of the U.S. dollar, which suggests potentially considerable fiscal spillovers." Finally, what acts as a predictor of what? Am I right in focusing on spreads a leading indicator, or is it self-referential to a fault?  Learning From History: Examining Yield Spreads as a Predictor of Real Economic Activity
http://www.michiganjb.org/issues/51/text51a.pdf
"Whereas the term structure of interest rates has been consistently shown to contain information regarding real future economic activity, the comparative value of using yield spreads is less conclusive."

Historically the 1M USD Libor has been 10-15 bps lower than the upper band of the target Fed Funds rate, and 35-40 bps above the lower band. However, since August 2016 it has been consistently above the upper band, reflecting a premium due to the recent scarcity of available USD funding for banks operating in Europe. 
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-30/europe-s-perfect-dollar-storm This scarcity isn't going to disappear over the next few months, hence after the Fed increases its Fed funds target rates by 25 bps in March, the 1M USD Libor will move above 1 %. There is a FOMC meeting on 13-14 June, and there is strong speculation that the Fed will hike again at that meeting. A rate hike begins to be priced into the 1M Libor approximately one month before the meeting, hence if markets expect another hike in June it will already start to be reflected in the rate at end of May.
Way out of my league on this one but I will start with it a little above the fed rate and if the fed raises rates in march  it could be close between .75 - 1.0 and 1. - 1.25.
